string.text: Rifled barrel
Rifling the barrel significantly improves accuracy and muzzle velocity, but prevents any further use of buckshot ammunition.
Installation of a muzzle brake
Installation of a muzzle brake mitigates some of the effects of recoil.
Tritium inserts
Installation of luminous night-sights allows for easier target acquisition in low-light conditions.
Ergonomic grip
Installation of a more comfortable grip.
Heavy-duty components
Replacing standard parts with analogs made of high-strength alloys increases the weapon's durability.
Lightweight alloy components
Replacing standard parts with lightweight alloys significantly reduces the weight of the gun.
Lightweight stock
Replacing the stock with a lightweight alternative reduces the overall weight of the weapon.
Rubberized buttplate
Installation of a rubberized buttplate on the stock absorbs much of the recoil felt by the shooter.
High-capacity magazine (10 rounds)
Higher-capacity magazines means fewer reloads during combat and improves the odds of survival.
Revision of the feeding mechanism
The ammunition feeding assembly has been redesigned to reduce the number of jams from cartridge misfeeding or alignment issues.
Chamber alignment
Careful fitting of parts to ensure a tighter seal on the chamber when fired, preventing the unwanted escape of propellant gasses and significantly increasing muzzle velocity.
Reinforced trigger assembly
A refined trigger assembly allows for a faster rate of fire at the expense of some overall reliability.
Lightweight forend
Replacing the forend with a lightweight alternative reduces the overall weight of the weapon.
Soft-recoil system
Reduces recoil, which in turn leads to more accurate follow-up shots.
Lapped component surfaces
Careful fitment and lapping of the moving surfaces minimizes motion outside of normal operating parameters, which has a positive effect on accuracy.
